awd_titl_txt: RCN-UBE Incubator: Course-based Undergraduate Research Experiences for Students Underrepresented in Biology
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to establish multi-faceted course-based undergraduate research experiences in cellular genetics and socio-biology for students underrepresented in biology. Community colleges serve almost half of the undergraduates in the U.S., including many minority low-income, first-generation, and underrepresented students, and many of these students are pursuing careers in biology. In this rapidly changing field, it is important that community college faculty have up-to-date teaching materials that reflect the most recent discoveries in biology and innovative data-analysis approaches. This network will bring appropriate teaching materials and offer professional development with the goal of incorporating cutting-edge biology research and high-impact teaching practices to improve student outcomes. Empowering community college faculty to increase student success will have a significant impact on the qualifications and diversity of the science and technology workforce. This project will take place at Edward Waters College, distinctively the state of Florida’s first independent institution of higher learning as well as Florida’s first institution established for the education of African Americans. 

The wide-spread use of DNA sequence data to enhance biological understanding, brings unique challenges for biology educators. Skills from computer and data sciences have become core competencies for students even though many biology faculty completed formal training without the computational expertise needed to effectively engage in this field. This network will bring together members of OMICS ((proteomics, transcriptomics, metabolomics)) education networks, leveraging their combined expertise to identify and curate common analysis tools, associated curricular and assessment materials, and faculty training strategies to facilitate the adoption of OMICS instruction. By making existing resources accessible, the network will enable current faculty to guide undergraduate biology students participating in authentic research projects. Such work will enhance the ability of students to become productive members of the technological work-force, to succeed in post-graduation studies in biology and related disciplines, and to be better informed citizens and decision makers. The network will develop a consensus set of vetted resources and training materials to be disseminated to the education community through a single web portal for use in undergraduate classrooms. The network will also advance preparation of adjunct biology faculty and recruitment of future junior faculty, who might not otherwise have the opportunity to build relationships with tenured faculty around the country. 

This project is being jointly funded by the Directorate for Biological Sciences, Division of Biological Infrastructure, and the Directorate for Education and Human Resources, Division of Undergraduate Education as part of their efforts to address the challenges posed in Vision and Change in Undergraduate Biology Education: A Call to Action (http://visionandchange/finalreport/).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
To the national calls to improve undergraduate biology education, we proposed to establish (initiate, develop, and implement) a Research Coordination Network (RCN) that enhances undergraduate biology education (UBE) by capitalizing on the advantages of Course-based Undergraduate Research Experience (CURE) in OMICS (e.g., genomics, proteomics, transcriptomics etc) as a model system. A year-long education-based project designed to stand alone authentic research experience for students with little to no prior lab skills. The projects aimed to establish a coordinated, long-term network by developing open-access teaching modules, assessment tools, and a full proposal for the long-term development of the network which will bring together individuals with diverse expertise and approaches to identify novel course-based research directions. The experts in the field of molecular biology, biotechnology and bioinformatics from Elizabeth City State University, Alabama State University, Bethune Cookman University, New Jersey Institute of Technology, Rutgers University, and University of Southern California have kindly accepted our invitation to speak to our underserved minority students deserving to learn about OMICS. There were a total of six (6) zoom lecture series on OMICS for our students. The ongoing information of our project were discussed in scientific conference and also in QUBES. Students were in favor of CURESUB over traditional course. In a traditional biology lab, it is all about rushing to finish the lab and the results are predetermine. But in the undergraduate education research environment, they are invested in their results and they are not rushing to get out of the lab. Students succeed in CURESUB. Students engage and develop ownership of the education research project. Overall the engagement in the larger scientific community (networking, presentations, institutional collaboration), increase in students interest and retention in the sciences. Above all, increase of self efficacy and confidence after the students conduct research project and generate good quality reports/presentation.
